==Proposals==

===Osama Shehata Proposal===
  â
[[Osama Shehata]], founder of The League of Arab States for Scientific Talent and former Chief Executive Officer of Technology Force Corporation, proposed on his website [http://www.osamaforegypt.com www.osamaforegypt.com] in February 2011 the formation of a Presidential Accountability Committee and the creation of a formal constitutional balance between the people and the government.
  â   â
Osama is certain that Egyptians have the absolute ability to escape poverty and create a robust economy that will provide prosperity for all Egyptians. However; to achieve this prosperity, Egyptians must strike a balance between the government and the people. First, we must form a Presidential Accountability Committee, whose responsibility will be to assess and audit the presidentâs performance and the performance of all members of government. This committee will consist of 3 elected members from each Egyptian province and from various fields. The committee will be autonomous, and its power will be protected against interference by any government or non-government entities, other than the will of the voting public.
  â   â
Second, we must formally empower the people to audit and prosecute the President and any member of government through a formal process if any of the government officials is guilty of corruption or abuse of power.
  â   â
Those two parts of the proposal will create the foundation of a robust system of social justice and give the people of Egypt that the power and the tools to eliminate obstacles to their prosperity.
  â   â
=== Mohamed Hassanein Heikal proposal ===
  â
[[Mohamed Hassanein Heikal]] suggested in an interview: {{citation needed|date=January 2011}} "We must establish a council of experts that we will call ''the Council of the state and the nation's faithful'', whose job it will be to formulate a new constitution and prepare the transition period between the current government regime and the new system."
  â   â
According to his proposal, well-known figures in Egypt would serve on this council, such as Ahmed Zewail, the 1999 Nobel Prize laureate in chemistry; [[Magdi Yacoub]], the renowned heart surgeon; Amr Moussa, [[Secretary-General]] of the [[League of Arab States]] and former Egyptian [[Foreign Minister]]; [[Omar Suleiman]], Minister without portfolio and director of the [[Egyptian General Intelligence Directorate]]; and Mohammed ElBaradei, the former director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency and the 2005 Nobel Prize laureate.
  â   â
Heikal explained that these individuals, by virtue of their age and status, would not be looking for a job and would not aspire to become the next President of Egypt, but would accept being assigned the task of preparing Egypt for its transfer to the younger generation. "They are leaders who can take Egypt from the stage of despair it is now in to the stage of hope." Several of these individuals that Heikal suggested have since become potential presidential candidates.
  â   â
===Emad Adeeb proposal===
  â
The [[Egyptian people|Egyptian]] [[Presenter|television host]] and [[political commentator]] [[Emad Adeeb]] proposed, in a phone call with the [[Al-Qahira Al-Youm]] [[TV show]], the making of a constitutional formulation that would allow for a "safe exit" for Egyptian presidents, so that Egypt can have living former presidents and not only dead former presidents. {{Citation needed|date=November 2010}}
  â   â
He also proposed to limit staying in presidency to two terms only, whether a single term would be for four years or six years. He further suggested a [[constitutional amendment]] in order to allow genuine [[pluralism]] and prohibit the consumption of power and lost separation of powers between various forms of Government.
  â   â
He added, "If there is any hope that the next line of presidents of Egypt will not belong to the 'Solid Foundation' â represented in the military or intelligence or from the Egyptian Federal Bureau of Investigation â it has to happen in the presence of President Mubarak". He also said, "If fate decided that institutions of the state should choose a president in the absence of President Mubarak â for any of the constitutional reasons set forth on the absence of the President â it is certain in my mind that the next President of Egypt will be from the 'Solid Foundation.'"
  â   â
He also said in another interview to [[Al Shorouk (Egyptian newspaper)|Al-Shorouk newspaper]] that the Egyptian people and citizens are with President Mubarak, but not with ''the president's party'', by showing that in the last voting Mubarak won the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2005|2005 presidential election]] by a larger proportion than that achieved by his [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] in the [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2005|2005 parliamentary election]]. {{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
